bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Alderman [Micajah] Perry, June 1732

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant Alderman [Micajah] Perry, June 1732, to alert him to renewed attacks upon the proprietary in the current assembly, and to send a record of "their votes" as he has to Thomas Lord Fairfax. He relates the problems ship masters are having in finding complete cargoes, and hopes this will mean a better market for tobacco.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Alderman [Micajah] Perry, June 1732

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
June 1732
Alderman Perry

div1.p:
I writ to you by the Rebeca at some Length about my Lord
Fairfax's Affairs. The Burgesses are now making a fresh attack against
his Lordship's grant as you will see by their Votes, which I have thought it my
Duty by this first Opportunity to transmit to his Lordship tht he may be upon
his Guard in the Defence of his Estate; & I send also a Copy of these Votes for your
Perusal. The Money they voted for solliciting their Petition in the Former
Session was disallowed by the Council; but whether it will meet with the
same Fate now I cannot take upon me to say. I expect the Gentlemen of
our Revenue will leave no Stone unturned to carry their Point for
Reasons I have formerly mentioned to you.

Captain Bradby of the Spotswood hath lately visited me & makes
a heavy Complaint of the Little Hopes he is in of getting his Ship near Loaded, & names
a great many more in the same Circumstances with himself; & I am
advised that the Ships will not be near loaded in James River; Capt.Malbon Bradby
tells me he hath writ these stories to You both by the Rebeca & by Brooks. I have
done all in my Power towards Loading your ships. Seabrook they say will
get full. What Dove will be able to do he can't yet tell. Your chartered Ship
takes a great deal away from him. We flatter ourselves these Things will
have a great Influence upon the Markets towards our Relief under our
Unhappy Circumstances. I am,

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Letter book, 1731 July 9-1732 July 13 , Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

[1] The Rebecca was probably a London ship; she was of 300 tons, had a crew of 11, and was commanded by Samuel Malbon in 1731-32. (Adm. 65/195, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)

[2] The Spotswood was a London ship commanded by James Bradby, 1727-1732, and was owned by Micajah Perry. (Adm 68/195, 70r ff., found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia. See Carter to Micajah Perry 1730 April 16.)

[3] Christopher Brooks commanded the Cambridge, a vessel of 100 tons and 11 men owned by London merchants Haswell and Brooks in 1729. (Survey Report 6801 summarizing Adm. 68/195, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)

[4] The Bailey was a London ship owned by William Dawkins and commanded at various times by Adam Graves (1725-1730) and by Thomas Dove (1731-1732). She was a vessel of some 250 tons and carried 15-17 crew members. (Survey report 6801 summarizing Adm. 68/195, 156v, and other data in Adm. 68/194 and /196, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia; A letter of Carter's to Dawkins 1732 May 12 refers to "your ship Bailey." as does a letter of 1738 May 10 from Carter's executors to Dawkins 1738 May 10.)
